explanation: detect_cpu_core_count itself does not call memcmp, but it delegates to mhd_tool_get_system_cpu_count and mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count; any use of memcmp that could violate the MISRA rule will occur in those functions or in their platform-specific helpers. To determine whether memcmp is used to compare null‑terminated strings you must therefore inspect:  - mhd_tool_get_system_cpu_count and all of its callees (mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_special_api_, mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_sysctl_, mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_sysconf_, and the two fallback helpers) because these implementations may contain memcmp calls on system/OS strings.  - mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count and all of its platform-specific implementations (sched_getaffinity_, cpuset_getaffinity_, sched_getaffinity_np_, w32_) because they may likewise use memcmp on null‑terminated strings.  - memcmp itself (the symbol) so the analyzer can locate every invocation and verify the operands (length and whether operands are NUL-terminated strings) to decide if the MISRA rule is violated.
